It probably doesn't matter and your example worked fine but the trucks fuel efficiency doesn't drop that much. It would take a large bus with 70-80 giraffsternauts to drag the tow trucks fuel consumption down to 5-6 mpg. This is why trucks are efficient. BUT empty fuel consumption is still only 10-13 mpg. This is why good freight prices and brokering is crucial to helping truckers make money, keeping less trucks on the road, and helping the economy. Oh and fuel storage on trucks is usually 100-400 gallons

This reminds me of people trying to outsmart manufacturers in multicopters (the so badly named drones) putting bigger batteries..

the thing for example is standard flown with a 2000mAh battery (200g) and lasts 10m.. people then go and say "oh but i modified mine and put a 3000mAh! it will fly 15m! ".. but no.. that 3000mAh weights 300g ..extra 100g so the motors need to spin faster and draw more power to lift those extra 100g..so the range wont be 15m.. and it gets worst the more weight as the motors need to draw more and more power spinning faster and losing efficiency due to prop drag and heat..

planes and rockets work simular.. extra payload or extra fuel will cost you

The government, the entity of waste and inefficiency, pays beyond full price for partial payloads to the ISS. These missions they land on land because they have the excess fuel / delta V

Primate clients use full payloads - they care about their value for the money - pay less get more - the low orbit missions land on the barge, the geosynchronous missions can't be landed.

comment_text: Elon Musk is making space great again!

Huh - I was looking for the music in the video, since it has a really cool sound to it (reminds me of M83 near the end) and was surprised to see that you make it yourself! That's really cool! I wasn't expecting to follow a soundcloud channel from your videos :P

As for the giraffe metaphor... eh, it's pretty decent! I feel like you should have started with the base level, "heavier payloads can't fly back as far, and here's why" to set the context, but the rest was fine, and the maps were well done.

Keep it up!

I like what you talk about, but please, stop doing "baby" talk. It's not funny.

Your analogy is far too concerned with the mass of the payload, not the destination. CRS-10's payload was a lot more than 4,200kg. That's just the dry mass of the Dragon capsule, and doesn't include the mass of the fuel and cargo the capsule was carrying. CRS-10 was heavier than both the other launches you mentioned.

The major difference is the destination of the orbit. GTO launches require the rocket to accelerate much more, burning up a lot more fuel.

One other minor quibble... LZ-1 is at the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, not the Kennedy Space Center.
